name: El Ladron de Agua

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We chose this hotel based on other Tripadvisor reviews and weren't disappointed. Perfectly located in the old town, with views of the Alhambra the hotel is a welcoming, friendly place. The property is decorated to a high standard, with an interesting mix of modern and traditional design. The rooms are a decent size and the bathrooms well equipped. There is free internet access available in the lounge room and breakfast, which is included in the price, is served in the cosy cellar. Would highly recommend this place, it's perfectly situated for getting to the old town, Alhambra and the centre of Granada.
reviews.title: Gorgeous hotel

reviews.text: The hotel is in a good location but the rooms are very small and not very comfortable.
reviews.title: Small rooms

reviews.text: I booked a five night stay after enrolling in a Spanish language course in Granada. The hotel was a beautiful blend of original architecture and modern amenities. I stayed in Melissandra room which did not have a view and was noisy but clean and comfortable with a wonderful steamy hot shower and lovely touches like dried flowers in a vase on the writing table. Breakfast was 9 euro and started at 8 am. I arrived on Sunday night and advised the staff that I was expected to be at my language school at 8 am for an orientation the following day. The lady said that breakfast would be ready for me by 7/7:30 am no problem, but when I arrived the next morning nothing had been set up. The gentleman at the front desk took out some pre-sliced fruit from the refrigerator and served me a cup of tea. I sat in the bar area and ate a few bites of the fruit before heading out for the day, still hungry. The full breakfast was much more substantial and quite nice. I was curious to see if they would charge me for the first day's breakfast in the end. Sure enough they did. I was not prepared to argue over 9 euro so I did not raise the issue but it is worth warning other people about. I did not find the staff to be particular friendly, rather frosty in fact. I asked if they could assist in booking an afternoon guided walk in the surrounding Sierra Nevada mountains and it appeared as though no one ever asked that question before. I ended up getting useful information from a British classmate who runs a hotel outside of town and had a fabulous hike one afternoon starting from a village called Monachill. Overall a good experience with some minor annoyances.
reviews.title: Charming hotel, slightly frosty hotel staff

reviews.title: Wonderful in every way
reviews.text: Everything about this hotel is special -- from the lobby, to the rooms named after famous Spanish authors ( complete with their portrait and books about them in each room), to the beds, jacuzzis in the bathrooms, location and service.

reviews.title: Exquisite
reviews.text: If you go to Granada, this is THE place to stay.

Four of us stayed here for a 50th birthday celebration in the beautiful city of Granada, and the Hotel provided all it said on the tin. The staff were helpful, spoke English, and arranged tickets and trips for us.
reviews.title: What a gem! Book early!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Several members on Tripadvisor warned of the street noise. It was true, it could be loud on Friday and Saturday night until about 2.30am. But earplugs were recommended, and I have to say they are a must for an unbroken sleep. But don't let this deter you. I loved the Hotel and the City. In fact I loved the City so much that when i returned home, I enrolled for a full months language course in the Albaicin through November, and the Hotel staff invited me to call in for coffee during my visit. I don't think that would happen in Britain. Well done El Ladron de Agua.
reviews.title: beautiful property, great staff, lovely rooms

reviews.text: What a lovely hotel! The location is perfect. You can hop on a bus for 1 euro and get to the Alhambra. The hotel lobby, within a courtyard, is just a welcoming oasis when you first stepped into the hotel.
reviews.title: Better location than the others
Amazing Room, Even Better Staff
reviews.text: My fiancee and I stayed here at the beginning of August. We booked the Generalife Suite, the best room in the hotel, with views of the Alhambra. The room was great, although could use a little more color. The view from the balcony was spectacular. The location of the hotel is great too, central to everything. Above all, the staff are out of this world. The best are Elena, at the reception who has a wonderful smile and went out of her way to help me find a pharmacy at midnight when my fiancee was feeling sick. Also, the night manager was awesome, and brought us up bottled water to the room while my fiancee was sick and refused to take a tip when I offered. Overall, a great place, well worth it. The only downside, which is a consideration for the Generalife Suite at least, was the noise from the street, even during the night.

reviews.title: Nice Place for a stay in Granada
reviews.text: We've just returned from staying at this hotel for two days. It is an interesting hotel and the staff are friendly but there is a noise problem, particularly if you are a light sleeper.

reviews.title: Our favorite!
reviews.text: We didn't dine here but the breakfast was OK but not a great deal of choice. Very handy for everything in Granada as it was only a 10 minute walk from the city and if you want to explore the Albacin, you're actually at the base of it at this hotel.

reviews.title: Like staying in an art gallery
reviews.text: My husband and I and our 15 year old daughter stayed at this lovely hotel in June in the Generalife room. This was a very large room with classic mudejar decor and a jacuzzi tub. It was bright but did face the street side so there was a little road noise, but we were fine with earplugs (a must for Spain). The staff was the friendliest and most helpful of any where we stayed in Spain (Seville, Madrid), especially Olga, who prepared a delicious, light tapas dinner for us on our final night. The lobby was beautiful and the views out our windows of the Alhambra and the city were to die for. We did not have breakfast at the hotel due to other plans, early departure, etc. I highly recommend lunch at the outdoor patio at the Parador de Granada (Alhambra grounds). We would definitely stay here again!

reviews.title: Charming hotel in Granada
reviews.text: El Ladron de Agua (which means water thief) is a superb small, character hotel. It has amazing touches like a bubbling water feature in the middle of an open courtyard- very restful -which is ringed by balconies with rooms- and big colourful wrap around artwork in the foyer. The dark woodwork, the artwork, the furniiture and bathrooms of the rooms are beautiful - a mix of very contemporary and historical detail. We stayed in a special double, which was great - our room was a bit dark but it was quiet. Some rooms face the front which would probably be brighter but potentially noisier. If you are a couple- I would suggest asking for twin beds as the double beds in Spain tend to be small. There is a room off the courtyard which feels like you are in someone's living room with free internet access and a bookcase. Art is on the walls throughout the hotel - giving it a gallery feeling. The breakfast is in a cellar of sorts- and was very good (not cheap though). The location is directly below the hill where the Alhambra sits- and is right in the Albayzin area. The only problem is if you are arriving by car- it's impossible! I would reccommend leaving your car at a garage outside the old quarter and getting to the hotel by taxi. The staff were very helpful, courteous and spoke good English. All in all a very memorable stay. NOTE one of us almost got pick pocketed right outside the hotel so be on guard.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed for two nights in August. Absolutely no need for a car as the local transport is first class. Parking relatively easy. Whilst you are at the base of the Alhambra, unless you have the constitution of a mountain goat it's advisable to get a bus to visit the attraction (1E) as the climb is near vertical! On the flat, a stroll of 1 minute to a local square with restaurants, bars and 3 minutes to the Cathedral and shopping area. The hotel is very serene, with good standards. There are only about 12 rooms. Because of the narrow, pedestrianised streets, early morning refuse collection seems the norm, but it was a small price to pay for such a good find.
reviews.title: Great Location, lovely City.

description: A building from the 16th century has become a hotel, taking its spirit from the essence of Juan Ramón Jimenez’s journey and his poems. Its privileged location in the heart of Granada, at the foot of the Albayzin; its rooms bathed in the light of the Alhambra; its colonnaded patio; its lounge, vestibule and well/cistern… all these charms will lead you to the sound of water, and to a peace that will give you inner harmony.
